detail.content: The Department of Radiology | Radiology                                      Skip to main content                      Patient Care       Faculty & Staff Directory       Events       Careers       Donate                                                                                                                                                                             Radiology                                                                                  Home   About Us   Patient Care   For Healthcare Professionals   Research   Education                                  Home            Print  Email               - A + A                                                                                                                                           The Department of Radiology                                                      For over one hundred years, The Department of Radiology at NYU Langone Medical Center has advanced the practice of radiology to serve the healthcare needs of patients and physicians. Today, we offer comprehensive and state-of-the-art imaging examinations and image-guided procedures to support NYU Langone Medical Center, a world-class patient-centered integrated academic medical center that is one of the nation’s premier centers for excellence in healthcare, biomedical research and medical education.                                                                         Research                        Our mission in the Department of Radiology at NYU Langone Medical Center is to transform the field of Radiology to improve the lives of people.       More               Education                            The NYU Langone Department of Radiology takes great pride in training and educating radiologists of all ages and experiences. Our main education goal is to help shape the future leaders of radiology.       More               For Healthcare Professionals                        The NYU Langone Department of Radiology continues to improve its services and imaging in order to better serve of referring physicians and patients.       More                                                                                                                                       NYU Langone Medical Center       Student Login       Library                 Policies & Disclaimers

Below is a list of our sites separated by borough. Please click on any link to get further information on the location, hours of operation, and services provided at each imaging center. Black Portraiture[s] II: Imaging the Black Body and Re-staging: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content          < back        Black Portraiture[s] II: Imaging the Black Body and Re-staging Histories  Event Date and Time: May 28, 2015 – May 31, 2015 TBD Location: Villa La Pietra Via Bolognese, 120 50139 Firenze, Italy The conference and exhibition will offer comparative perspectives on the historical and contemporary role played by photography, art, film, literature, and music in referencing the image of the black body in the West. It will be held in Florence, Italy, in May 28-31, 2015—as a sequel to five conferences held over the past six years. The most recent conference in the series was held in Paris, France in January 2013, where it attracted over 400 attendees. As on those occasions, the sixth conference will bring together artists and scholars from an assortment of disciplines and practices, including art history, fashion, dance, theater, and studio art, in wide-ranging conversations about imaging the black body. In this context, Black Portraitures II: Imaging the Black Body and Re-staging Histories , explores the impulses, ideas, and techniques undergirding the production of self-representation and desire, and the exchange of the gaze from the 19th century to the present day in fashion, film, art, and the archives. Discussions will focus on aesthetics, vernacular style, fashion, and ethnographics in describing a sense of place and identity. The conference will also invite visitors to conduct a diverse visual reading of the notion of a black portrait while challenging conventional perspectives on identity, beauty, cosmopolitanism, and community in Africa and its diaspora. Through a series of panels and individual speakers, the presentations will include a wide range of discussions relating to the topic. Some anticipated panels and presentations include: Re-Significations: European Blackamoors, Africana Reading and More The Sweetest Taboo: Theorizing Black Female Pleasure, Agency, and Desire within Black Feminism Owning the Hiphop Body: Hiphop Archive and Research Institute (HARI) Representing Blackness & Queerness: the Art & Politics of Questionable Juxtapositions The Black Body in Translation The Portrait & Studio Photographer Who's Black Where  Exhibition This year’s conference will strike an innovative note by including a focus on depictions of the black body within the art collections of NYU’s Villa La Pietra, a historical villa and home of the New York University Florence program. These assets include a collection of sculptures and paintings representing ornamental black images that have come to be known as “Blackamoors.” Embedded within centuries-old discourses, cross-cultural encounters, and artistic productions shaped by migration, conquest, servitude, and exile, these images present a rich opportunity to deconstruct, compare, and contextualize the myriad portrayals of the black body in western societies from multidisciplinary angles. As such, they constitute an invaluable resource to fulfill the mandate of producing critical knowledge of African and African diasporic identities and representations shared by NYU and Harvard’s Hutchins Center. It is in the spirit of this mandate that we seek to invite historians, art historians, photographers, sculptors, filmmakers, musicians, designers, and choreographers to respond to and continue the discussion focusing on the black body in the West as well as the “Blackamoor” collection as a trope.  Conclusion What are we to make of these extraordinary images that have played a crucial role in shaping identities and ideals of the black body for over 500 years? We hope to engage in a discussion that will change perceptions and publish an extensive catalog of the works discussed in order to counter the perceived notions of the black body, and explore ways in which to see how these collected works are viewed as beautiful renderings, as well. New York University is a leading center of intellectual exchanges across all sorts of boundaries whether geographical, cultural, artistic, or disciplinary. NYU’s campus at Villa La Pietra is the ideal location for this discussion as it houses an impressive collection of Blackamoors—a series of sculptured images of Africans in various states of servitude and decoration. In this context, Villa La Pietra is an invaluable resource, providing an invigorating forum for producing knowledge, engaging its immediate society, and connecting NYU’s academic and civic activities in New York City with the worlds of Florence, Italy.  Visit our event page for more information about the program and to register for the event . Also make plans to attend The 56th Venice Biennale while in Italy. It is a train ride from Florence. The Venice Biennale has announced that next year’s Okwui Enwezor-organized edition will open a month earlier. While the Biennale usually opens during the first week of June, the 2015 Biennnale is slated to take place May 6 to 8. For more information about Black Portraiture{s} II: Imaging the Black Body and Re-staging Histories , please visit www.blackportraitures.info      Photography & Imaging Web Site  Photography & Imaging 721 Broadway, 8th Floor New York, NY 10003               Phone:       212 998 1930               Fax:       212 995 4068 photo.tsoa@nyu.edu           Undergraduate Admissions Graduate Admissions Academic Services Student Life Financial Aid and Scholarships Career Development Counseling Services International Students Incoming Students Graduation Forms What is Special Programs?
